Used to calculate/estimate an endpoint based other available endpoints.
Used to calculate/estimate an endpoint based other available endpoints.

classes.note: Used to hold the relevant value ranges for a certain endpoint.

attributes.name: measurable_min
attributes.note: the lowest measurable value for an endpoint

attributes.name: measurable_max
attributes.note: the highest measurable value for an endpoint

attributes.name: bio_relevance_min
attributes.note: the lowest biological relevant value for an endpoint

attributes.name: bio_relevance_max
attributes.note: the highest biological relevant value for an endpoint

attributes.name: match_threshold
attributes.note: a score equal or below this threshold is considered similar enough to be a direct match

attributes.name: nomatch_threshold
attributes.note: a similarity score above this threshold is considered a mismatch between the two objects for this endpoint

enumerations.name: ConstituentRole
enumerations.note: Indicates the 'role' of a constituent material in relationship to its composing material. Which roles a constituent may have depends on properties of both the constituent itself and the composer.

enumerates.name: 'core'
enumerates.note: A 'solid?' 'chemical' representing a substantial part of or the entire 'core' chemistry of a non hollow 'nano-object' ( e.g. 'spheres', 'platelets', 'discs', 'rods', 'wires', 'cubes').

enumerates.name: 'shell'
enumerates.note: A 'chemical' surrounding a 'core' or other 'shell'. ( not yet clearly distinguished by definition from 'coating' )

enumerates.name: 'coating'
enumerates.note:
A 'chemical' surrounding either a 'core', 'wall', 'shell', 'coating' or 'aggregated' or 'agglomerated'

WIKIPEDIA
Functionalization is the introduction of organic molecules or polymers on the surface of the nanoparticle. The surface coating of nanoparticles determines many of their physical and chemical properties, notably stability, solubility, and targeting. A coating that is multivalent or polymeric confers high stability. Functionalized nanomaterial-based catalysts can be used for catalysis of many known organic reactions.

enumerates.name: 'corona'
enumerates.note: A protein based coating.. (to be deprecated as role) as this overlaps with coating.

enumerates.name: 'wall'
enumerates.note:
A 'chemical' acting as a single or multiple 'walls'  in a nanotube. (eg. SWCNT, MWCNT)

Wall (the chemical of a tube)

enumerates.name: 'solid matrix'
enumerates.note: A solid material representing the matrix material of a composite potentially hosting/containing other dispersed materials.

enumerates.name: 'liquid medium'
enumerates.note:
A liquid substance being the dominant material potentially containing other dispersed, dissolved materials.

Liquid medium (a liquid representing the host medium of a suspension, dispersion, etc.)

enumerates.name: 'gaseous medium'
enumerates.note:
A gaseous substance being the dominant material potentially containing other materials dispersed in it (like aerosols)

Gaseous medium (a gas representing the host gaseous medium of an aerosol, etc.)

enumerates.name: 'substrate'
enumerates.note:
A solid substance acting as the 'substrate' for another material in roles like: 'film', 'structured film', 'surface bound', 'surface').

Substrate (a solid representing the substrate of film, structured film, etc.)

enumerates.name: 'surface'
enumerates.note: A layer of material attached to a substrate material

enumerates.name: 'film'
enumerates.note: Film (a very thin homogenous layer attached to a substrate material)

enumerates.name: 'structured film'
enumerates.note: Structured film (a very thin structured layer attached to a substrate material)

enumerates.name: 'surface bound'
enumerates.note: Surface bound (particulate matter bound to a surface)

enumerates.name: 'dispersed'
enumerates.note: Dispersed (particulate matter dispersed in a solid or liquid medium or gaseous medium (aerosol))

enumerates.name: 'dissolved'
enumerates.note: Dissolved (dissolved chemical in a liquid or solid medium)

enumerates.name: 'mixed'
enumerates.note: Mixed (a material mixed with other mixed materials)

enumerates.name: 'layered'
enumerates.note: Layered (a solid layer, layered with other layers)  (eg. laminate)

enumerates.name: 'aggregated'
enumerates.note: Aggregated (strongly bounded with other particles)

enumerates.name: 'agglomerated'
enumerates.note: Agglomerated (weakly bounded with other particles)

enumerates.name: 'impurity'
enumerates.note: An unintended chemical being part of the composing material  (eg. contaminant)

enumerates.name: 'contaminant'
enumerates.note: Deprecated (impurity only)

enumerates.name: 'container'
enumerates.note: Container (a substance, containing other materials, substances (glass of a bottle))

enumerates.name: 'contained'
enumerates.note: Contained (the material/substance/chemical contained by a container material)

enumerates.name: 'capsule'
enumerates.note: Capsule (a substance/chemical the capsule wall is made of)

enumerates.name: 'encapsulated'
enumerates.note: Encapsulated (a substance/chemical inside the capsule wall)

enumerates.name: 'dope'
enumerates.note: An intentional introduced impurity to alter certain material properties like electrical or optical properties (new..)

enumerates.name: 'additive'
enumerates.note: Constituent which is intentionally added to stabilise the substance and only for this purpose

enumerates.name: 'main chemical'
enumerates.note: A chemical representing the main constituent of a substance

enumerations.name: PhysicalState
enumerations.note:
‘Depending on the ‘material-class’ up to five ‘states’ are available: ‘ions’, ‘solid’, ‘liquid’, ‘gas’ and ‘mixture’. Besides the three most common phases of matter: ‘solid’, ‘liquid’, ‘gas’ two other ‘states’ are added. ‘Ions’ representing matter in its ionic form either positive or negative charged and ‘mixtures’ representing the state of combinations of matter in different phases. The state ‘mixture’ can only occur if a ‘substance’ is composed of other ‘substances’ in different states.
IUCLID phrasegroup = A19

enumerates.name: ions
enumerates.note: Used to indicate that matter is in its ionic state. eg. Ag+

enumerates.name: solid
enumerates.note:
Used to indicate the substance and all of its constituents are in solid phase. (eg. Ag(s) )
[2381]

enumerates.name: liquid
enumerates.note:
Used to indicate a substance is in liquid state. ( e.g. H2O(aq) )
[2038]

enumerates.name: gas
enumerates.note:
Used to indicate a substance is in gaseous state. ( e.g. CO2(g) )
[2830]

enumerates.name: 'mixed state'
enumerates.note: The mixed state  can only occur if a ‘substance’ is composed of other ‘substances’ in different states.

enumerations.name: NanomaterialOrigin
enumerations.note:
ISO/TS 80004-1:2015 
 ('natural') added by ThinkWorks

enumerates.name: 'engineered'
enumerates.note: Designed for specific purpose of function

enumerates.name: 'manufactured'
enumerates.note: Intentionally produced to have selected properties or composition.

enumerates.name: 'incidental'
enumerates.note: Generated as an unintentional by-product of a process

enumerates.name: 'natural'
enumerates.note: Generated/transformed by natural/environmental processes (not in ISO but in EC definition)

enumerations.name: NOShape
enumerations.note: IUCLID picklist?? => {flake, irregular, prismatic, rod, spherical, tubular, other}

enumerations.name: CoatingOrigin
enumerations.note: Indicates the origin of the specific coating/shell. Multiple coatings/shells may exist each with its own origin.

enumerates.name: 'engineered'
enumerates.note: Intentionally functionalized to alter one or more properties/functionalities of the coated nanomaterial

enumerates.name: 'from matrix'
enumerates.note: an unintended coating due to degradation of the matrix still containing the NOAA. (eg. paint particles due to sanding containg nano-particles) (check?)

enumerates.name: 'from environment'
enumerates.note: a (unintended?) coating as a result of environmental chemical processes. (eg. Ag2S(s) NP )

enumerates.name: 'biological'
enumerates.note: a (unintended) coating due to biological  interaction.

enumerations.name: CompositionCategory
enumerations.note: ThinkWorks introduced

enumerates.name: 'organic compound'
enumerates.note: An organic compound is generally any 'chemical' that contains carbon.

enumerates.name: 'organic matter'
enumerates.note: Organic matter is matter composed of organic compounds.

enumerates.name: 'inorganic compound'
enumerates.note: An inorganic compound is generally any chemical lacking carbon, so not an 'organic compound' or water.

enumerates.name: 'inorganic matter'
enumerates.note: Inorganic matter is matter composed of solely inorganic compounds.

enumerates.name: 'hybrid material'
enumerates.note: Hybrid materials are composites consisting of two or more 'chemicals' at the nanometer or molecular level, at least one being 'organic'. (Wikipedia)

enumerates.name: 'mixture'
enumerates.note: any combination of different material categories (eg. ) above the nano or molecular size.

enumerations.name: SubstanceCategory
enumerations.note:
See also,  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixture  (extended with 'gas', 'liquid', 'solid', 'composite' , 'capsule' and 'none')

When dispersing NOAA's (Nano-Objects, Aggregates and Agglomerates) in the different continuous media the categories will become nano-enabled and map onto the ISO80004_Categories.

enumerates.name: 'gas'
enumerates.note: single continuous gas

enumerates.name: 'liquid'
enumerates.note: single continuous liquid

enumerates.name: 'solid'
enumerates.note: single continuous solid

enumerates.name: 'powder'
enumerates.note: a heterogenous mixture of colloidal and/or coarse particulate solids < 100 µm (eg, suger powder)

enumerates.name: 'gas mixture'
enumerates.note: homogeneous mixture of different gases (eg. air)

enumerates.name: 'liquid solution'
enumerates.note: a gas, liquid or solid dissolved in another continuous liquid medium (eg. oxygen in water, alcoholic beverages, sugar in water)

enumerates.name: 'aerosol'
enumerates.note: liquid colloid between 1 nm and 1 µm  dispersed in a gas (eg. fog, mist, vapor, hair sprays)

enumerates.name: 'fluid foam'
enumerates.note: colloidal or coarse gas (bubbles) in a continuous liquid medium (e.g. whipped cream, shaving cream)

enumerates.name: 'emulsion'
enumerates.note: (colloidal or larger) liquid dispersed in another continuous liquid medium (eg. milk, mayonnaise, hand cream)

enumerates.name: 'sol'
enumerates.note: a colloidal solid dispersed in a continuous liquid medium (eg, pigmented ink, blood)

enumerates.name: 'solid foam'
enumerates.note: colloidal gas dispersed in a continuous solid medium (eg. aerogel, styrofoam, pumice)

enumerates.name: 'gel'
enumerates.note: a colloidal liquid dispersed in a continuous solid medium (eg. agar, gelatin,silicagel)

enumerates.name: 'solid sol'
enumerates.note: a colloidal solid dispersed in another solid continuous medium (eg, cranberry glass)

enumerates.name: 'solid aerosol'
enumerates.note: solid colloid between 1 nm and 1 µm  dispersed in a gas (eg. smoke, nano and ultra fine powder)

enumerates.name: 'solid aerosol, dust'
enumerates.note: coarse solid exceeding 1 µm dispersed in a gas (eg. dust, superfine powder, granular powder)

enumerates.name: 'suspension'
enumerates.note: a coarse dispersion of a solid in a continuous liquid medium (eg, mud, chalk powder suspended in water)

enumerates.name: 'solid mixture'
enumerates.note: a heterogenous mixture of a coarse solid mixed with another solid (eg, gravel)

enumerates.name: 'composite'
enumerates.note: a heterogenous mixture of colloidal or coarse solids dispersed in another solid continuous medium (eg, cranberry glass, granite)

enumerates.name: 'solid solution'
enumerates.note: a gas, liquid or solid dissolved in another continuous solid medium (eg. hydrogen in metals, amalgam, hexane in parraffin wax)

enumerates.name: 'water-like'
enumerates.note: low, like water ( < 1 cP)

enumerates.name: 'oil-like'
enumerates.note: medium, like oil (~ 100 cP)

enumerates.name: 'paste-like'
enumerates.note: high, like paste (> 1000 cP)

enumerates.name: 'solid object'
enumerates.note: solid object (> 10 mm)

enumerates.name: 'broken solid'
enumerates.note: broken solid (3 - 10 mm)

enumerates.name: 'granular solid'
enumerates.note: granular solid (0.1 - 3 mm)

enumerates.name: 'granular powder'
enumerates.note: granular powder (10 - 100 µm)

enumerates.name: 'superfine powder'
enumerates.note: superfine powder (1 - 10 µm)

enumerates.name: 'ultrafine powder'
enumerates.note: ultrafine powder (100 nm - 1 µm)

enumerates.name: 'nano powder'
enumerates.note: nanoscaled particles (1 nm - 100 nm)

enumerates.name: '0D'
enumerates.note: 0D, no external dimensions in the nanoscale ~[1..100nm]

enumerates.name: '1D'
enumerates.note: 1D, one external dimension in the nanoscale ~[1..100nm], the two others are significantly larger

enumerates.name: '2D'
enumerates.note: 2D, two external dimensions in the nanoscale ~[1..100nm], the third significantly larger

enumerates.name: '3D'
enumerates.note: 3D, all three external dimensions in the nanoscale ~[1..100nm]

enumerates.name: continuous
enumerates.note: no particles in medium

enumerates.name: dissolved
enumerates.note: particle size (< 1 nm)

enumerates.name: colloid
enumerates.note: particle size (1 nm – 1 µm)

enumerates.name: coarse
enumerates.note: particle size (> 1 µm)

enumerates.name: laminar
enumerates.note: Laminar flow (or streamline flow) occurs when a fluid flows in parallel layers, with no disruption between the layers.[1] At low velocities, the fluid tends to flow without lateral mixing, and adjacent layers slide past one another like playing cards.

enumerates.name: transitional
enumerates.note: A flow in which the viscous and Reynolds stresses are of approximately equal magnitude. It is transitional between laminar flow and turbulent flow.

enumerates.name: turbulent
enumerates.note: Turbulent flow, type of fluid (gas or liquid) flow in which the fluid undergoes irregular fluctuations, or mixing, in contrast to laminar flow, in which the fluid moves in smooth paths or layers.

enumerations.name: CompactionClass
enumerations.note: Soil compaction class.

enumerates.name: low
enumerates.note: packing_density < 1.4

enumerates.name: medium
enumerates.note: packing density >= 1.4 and < 1.75

enumerates.name: high
enumerates.note: packing density > 1.75

enumerations.name: ISO80004_Category
enumerations.note: An ISO nanomaterial is considered to be either a NANO-OBJECT or a NANOSTRUCTURED MATERIAL as defined by the ISO/TS 80004-1:2011

enumerates.name: 'nanomaterial'
enumerates.note: Material with any external dimension in the nanoscale or having internal structure or surface structure in the nanoscale.   [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 2.3]

enumerates.name: 'nano-object'
enumerates.note: Material with one, two or three external dimensions in the nanoscale. [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 - 1:2011, definition 2.2]

enumerates.name: 'nano-particle'
enumerates.note: Nano-object (2.2) with all three external dimensions in the nanoscale (2.1)  [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 - 1:2011, definition 2.4]

enumerates.name: 'nanofibre'
enumerates.note: Nano-object (2.2) with two similar external dimensions in the nanoscale (2.1) and the third dimension significantly larger. [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 - 1:2011, definition 2.5]

enumerates.name: 'nanoplate'
enumerates.note: Nano-object (2.2) with one external dimension in the nanoscale (2.1) and the two other external dimensions significantly larger. [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 - 1:2011, definition 2.5]

enumerates.name: 'nanostructured material'
enumerates.note: Material having internal or surface structure in the nanoscale.   [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 2.11]

enumerates.name: 'nanostructured powder'
enumerates.note: Powder comprising nanostructured agglomerates (3.1.2), nanostructured aggregates (3.1.1), or other particles of nanostructured material (2.11)  [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.1]

enumerates.name: 'nanostructured aggregate'
enumerates.note: Aggregate (2.7) formed from nano-objects (2.2)  [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.1.1]

enumerates.name: 'nanostructured agglomerate'
enumerates.note: Agglomerate (2.8) of nano-objects (2.2), or agglomerate of nanostructured (2.10) aggregates (2.7).  [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.1.2]

enumerates.name: 'nanostructured core-shell particle'
enumerates.note: Particle consisting of a core and shell(s), where the diameter of the core or the thickness of the shell is in the nanoscale (2.1) [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.1.3]

enumerates.name: 'nanocomposite'
enumerates.note: Solid comprising a mixture of two or more phase-separated materials, one or more being nanophase (2.12) [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.2]

enumerates.name: 'solid nanofoam'
enumerates.note: Solid matrix filled with a second, gaseous phase, typically resulting in a material of much lower density, with a nanostructured (2.10) matrix, for example having nanoscale (2.1) struts and walls, or gaseous nanophase (2.12) consisting of nanoscale bubbles [closed nanofoam (2.15)], or both [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.3]

enumerates.name: 'nanoporous material'
enumerates.note: Solid material with nanopores (2.13) [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.4]

enumerates.name: 'fluid nanodispersion'
enumerates.note: Heterogeneous material in which nano-objects (2.2) or a nanophase (2.12) are dispersed in a continuous fluid phase of a different composition. [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.5]

enumerates.name: 'nanosuspension'
enumerates.note: Fluid nanodispersion (3.5) where the dispersed phase is a solid. [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.5.1]

enumerates.name: 'nano-emulsion'
enumerates.note: Fluid nanodispersion (3.5) with at least one liquid nanophase (2.12).  [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.5.2]

enumerates.name: 'liquid nanofoam'
enumerates.note: Fluid nanodispersion (3.5) filled with a second, gaseous nanophase (2.12), typically resulting in a material of much lower density. [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.5.3]

enumerates.name: 'nano aerosol'
enumerates.note: Fluid nanodispersion (3.5) with gaseous matrix and at least one liquid or solid nanophase (2.12) [including nano-objects (2.2)] [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004 -1:2011, definition 3.5.4]

enumerations.name: MaterialFunction
enumerations.note:
Indicates the intended function of the material or as constituent. Multiple functions per material are allowed. 
Relevant for safer by design. Still needs to be extended with other functions.

enumerates.name: 'antimicrobial agent'
enumerates.note:
the material has antimicrobial properties.
 http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/CHEBI_33281

enumerates.name: 'binder'
enumerates.note:
A 'binder' or binding agent is any 'material' or 'substance' that holds or draws other materials together to form a cohesive whole mechanically, chemically, by adhesion or cohesion.
http://purl.enanomapper.org/onto/ENM_8000174

enumerates.name: 'catalyst'
enumerates.note:
A catalysis is a chemical that increases the rate of a chemical reaction due to the participation, which is not consumed in the catalyzed reaction and can continue to act repeatedly. Often only tiny amounts of catalyst are required in principle.
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/CHEBI_35223

enumerates.name: 'electrical conductor'
enumerates.note: a material allowing the flow of an electric charge

enumerates.name: 'dispersant'
enumerates.note: A dispersant or a dispersing agent or a plasticizer or a superplasticizer is either a non-surface active polymer or a surface-active substance added to a suspension, usually a colloid, to improve the separation of particles and to prevent settling or clumping. Dispersants consist normally of one or more surfactants.

enumerates.name: 'solvent'
enumerates.note: A 'solvent' is a substance that dissolves a 'solute' (a chemically distinct liquid, solid or gas), resulting in a solution. A solvent is usually a liquid but can also be a solid, a gas, or a supercritical fluid.

enumerates.name: 'pigment'
enumerates.note: A 'pigment' is a material that changes the color of reflected or transmitted light as the result of wavelength-selective absorption.

enumerates.name: 'preservative'
enumerates.note: A 'preservative' is a substance or a chemical that is added to various products like food, beverages, pharmaceutical drugs, paints, biological samples, cosmetics, wood and many other products to prevent decomposition by microbial growth or by undesirable chemical changes.

enumerates.name: 'substance studied'
enumerates.note: Indicates that this material batch is the subject in an assay like a 'toxicity study'.

enumerates.name: 'test vehicle'
enumerates.note: Indicates that this substance is used as a vehicle or carrier for the 'substance studied'.

enumerates.name: 'uv filter'
enumerates.note: An UV filter is a material that blocks or absorbs ultraviolet (UV) light.

enumerates.name: 'thickening agent'
enumerates.note: A thickening agent or thickener is a substance which can increase the viscosity of a liquid without substantially changing its other properties. Thickeners may also improve the suspension of other ingredients or emulsions which increases the stability of the product.

enumerates.name: 'anticaking agent'
enumerates.note:
An anticaking agent is an additive placed in powdered or granulated materials to prevent the formation of lumps (caking).
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/CHEBI_77964

enumerates.name: 'other'
enumerates.note: Other material functions not yet covered.. Please report new functions!

enumerates.name: 'particle size'
enumerates.note: Represents the physical sizes of the particle in three dimensions. It is the primary size in case the particle is a Nano-object.

enumerates.name: 'Feret diameter'
enumerates.note: Feret’s diameter (maximum distance edge to edge);

enumerates.name: 'volume equivalent sphere diameter'
enumerates.note: D_volume = diameter of a sphere with the same volume as the particle

enumerates.name: 'surface equivalent sphere diameter'
enumerates.note: D_surface = diameter of a sphere with the same  surface as the particle

enumerates.name: 'Stokes equivalent sphere diameter'
enumerates.note: D_Stokes (= equivalent diameter corresponding to the diameter of a sphere with the same final settling velocity as the particle undergoing laminar flow in a fluid of the same density and viscosity)

enumerates.name: 'hydrodynamic equivalent sphere diameter'
enumerates.note:
Hydrodynamic equivalent diameter D_hydro (= diameter of a sphere with the same translational diffusion coefficient as the particle in the same fluid under the same conditions)

The diameter measured in Dynamic Light Scattering is called the hydrodynamic diameter and refers to the way a particle diffuses within a fluid. The diameter obtained by this technique is that of a sphere that has the same translational diffusion coefficient as the particle being measured.
The translational diffusion coefficient will depend not only on the size of the particle 'core', but also on any surface structure, as well as the concentration and type of ions in the medium. This means that the size will be larger than measured by electron microscopy, for example, where the particle is removed from its native environment.

enumerates.name: 'sieve equivalent sphere diameter'
enumerates.note: D_sieve (= equivalent diameter corresponding to the diameter of a sphere passing through a sieve of defined mesh size with square or circular apertures).

enumerates.name: 'aerodynamic equivalent sphere diameter'
enumerates.note:
The diameter in [nm] of an equivalent spherical particle with the same unit [1000 kg/m3] density and settling velocity in air as the NOAA under consideration. (ThinkWorks)
The aerodynamic diameter of an irregular particle is defined as the diameter of the spherical particle with a density of 1000 kg/m3 and the same settling velocity as the irregular particle. (Wikipedia)
The diameter of a sphere with unit density that has aerodynamic behavior identical to that of the particle in question; an expression of aerodynamic behavior of an irregularly shaped particle in terms of the diameter of an idealized particle. Particles having the same aerodynamic diameter may have different dimensions and shapes. 
[https://www.opentoxipedia.org/index.php/Aerodynamic_diameter]
[constraint, only relevant if medium.physical_state = gas]

enumerates.name: 'volume equivalent cylinder diameter'
enumerates.note: diameter and length of a cylinder with the same volume as the fibre like particle.

enumerates.name: 'volume equivalent disc'
enumerates.note: thickness and diameter of a disc with the same volume as the disc/platelett like particle.

enumerations.name: PSDWeighting
enumerations.note:
A particle size distribution can be represented in different ways with respect to the weighting of individual particles. The weighting mechanism will depend upon the measuring principle being used. 
When comparing particle size data for the same sample measured by different techniques, it is important to realize that the types of distribution being measured and reported can produce very different particle size results.

enumerates.name: 'mass based'
enumerates.note:
Here the contribution of each particle in the distribution relates to the mass of that particle (uniform density), i.e. the relative contribution will be proportional to (size)3. (check?)
IUCLID PhraseID 9150 = mass based distribution

enumerates.name: 'number based'
enumerates.note:
A counting technique such as image analysis will give a number weighted distribution where each particle is given equal weighting irrespective of its size. 
This is most often useful where knowing the absolute number of particles is important - in foreign particle detection for example - or where high resolution (particle by particle) is required.
IUCLID PhraseID 1822 => counted distribution

enumerates.name: 'volume based'
enumerates.note:
Here the contribution of each particle in the distribution relates to the volume of that particle (equivalent to mass if the density is uniform), i.e. the relative contribution will be proportional to (size)3.
IUCLID PhraseID 2457 = volumetric distribution

enumerates.name: 'light intensity based'
enumerates.note:
Dynamic light scattering techniques will give an intensity weighted distribution, where the contribution of each particle in the distribution relates to the intensity of light scattered by the particle. (unit ?)
not in IUCLID

enumerations.name: Dimension
enumerations.note: The three dimensions of an object.

enumerates.name: D1
enumerates.note: D1 is the shortest of three dimensions (x,y,z)

enumerates.name: D2
enumerates.note: D2 the dimension considered either equal or between D1 and D3

enumerates.name: D3
enumerates.note: D3 is the longest of three dimensions (x,y,z)

enumerations.name: OdourCategory
enumerations.note: IULCID phrasegroup  A100

enumerates.name: 'ammonia-like'
enumerates.note: IUCLID phrase 4759

enumerations.name: AssemblyStructure

classes.note: Abstract material, representing substances, products, articles, mixtures.

attributes.name: name
attributes.note: Name of the material, substance, nanoform or chemical in order to identify it within the case.

attributes.name: description
attributes.note: General description of the material, nanoform or chemical, to provide general information about it.

attributes.name: constituent_role
attributes.note:
Identifies the role of this specific material in relationship to its composing material. (ThinkWorks) (see PhysicalState)
Note! The role is not indicating its functional behaviour. It enables filtering and reasoning with specific constituents in any material.

attributes.name: physical_state
attributes.note: Indicates the physical state of the material. (ThinkWorks)

attributes.name: surface_index
attributes.note:
In case this material is a constituent the surface_index is used to indicate the relative position of it within the layout of the composing material. The surface_index is a relative value indicating the virtual layer this material is part of. 
The constituent(s) with the highest value are the most outward and considered the only chemicals to be in direct contact with the surrounding medium.

attributes.name: category
attributes.note: Indicates if the material is considered to be organic, inorganic or a combination. (completely defined by its constituents)

attributes.name: functions
attributes.note: Indicate which function(s) this material|constituent fulfils. (Important for Safer By Design.)

attributes.name: s_uuid_hs
attributes.note: This is a unique substance identifier equal to the one  in the eNanoMapper database. (when the material is constructed from the eNanoMapper database)

attributes.name: abrasive_wear_factor
attributes.note: Is this the correct unit? In IATA Oc-R-Indoor-2 => mm2/kgf (not verified)

expressions.name: chemistry
expressions.note: All chemicals defined within this material.  (the leaves of the constituent tree)

expressions.name: surface_chemistry
expressions.note: All chemicals defined within this material directly in contact with the surrounding (external) medium. (based on highest surface_index)

expressions.name: core_chemistry
expressions.note: All chemicals defined within this material with a surface_index equal or lower to the [core, wall, capsule ] chemicals with the lowest surface_index.

expressions.name: is_particulate
expressions.note: True if, the material is free to move within the composing material or surrounding medium.

expressions.name: name_path
expressions.note: The name with the preceeding path of composer names.

expressions.name: scenario
expressions.note: composer

expressions.name: v_self
expressions.note: This is the virtual self. It's always the self of the material object itself except in case of a proxy material object, then it results in the self of the original material the proxy is representing.

expressions.name: nano_constituents
expressions.note: All nanoforms contained within this material.

expressions.name: candidate_NFs
expressions.note: The candidate nanoform this material represents.Only Nanoform and CandidateNFProxy can represent one or more nanoforms.

composites.name: constituents
composites.note:
General, any material (composer) must define its constituents (any material) up to the level of the individual chemicals. There are constraints on the multiplicity and potential constituents per material class.
A 'chemical' may not have any constituents, any other material must have at least one constituent.

decendents.note:
A substance is defined in REACH by Article 3 and in CLP by Article 2 as:
 
'a chemical element and its compounds in the natural state or obtained by any manufacturing process, 
including any additive necessary to preserve its stability and any impurity deriving from the process used,
 but excluding any solvent which may be separated without affecting the stability of the substance or changing its composition.'
 
 REACH encompasses substances (mono-constituent, multi-constituent, UVCB substances and 'nanoform' (new!)) which all should be addressed as substances.

Represents an individual nanoform.
 
 A “nanoform” is a form of a natural or 20 manufactured substance consisting of particles, in an unbound state or as an aggregate or as an
 agglomerate and where, for 50 % or more of the particles in the number size distribution, one or more external dimensions is in the size range 1 nm-100 nm, including also by derogation 
 fullerenes, graphene flakes and single wall carbon nanotubes with one or more external dimensions below 1 nm.

attributes.name: is_HARN
attributes.note: To be considered a HARN at the Basic Information step of the Framework requires only that the NF has an elongated structure with an aspect ratio > 5:1 (European Chemicals Agency, 2019).

attributes.name: DN_HARN_can_deposit_in_distal_region_of_lung
attributes.note: In order to address this DN evidence that the NF has an aerodynamic diameter (Dae) of < 4 µm is required as this represents the respirable portion of inhalable particles that enter the non-ciliated alveoli (d50 = 4 μm) (BSI, 1993)

attributes.name: DN_HARNs_dissolve_very_slow_in_lung_lining_fluid
attributes.note: The half-life (t½ > 60 days) and dissolution rate (Kdiss < 1 ng/cm2/h) thresholds were set to ensure only very slowly dissolving HARNs meet the DN criteria. These thresholds are based on literature from durability and biopersistence studies of mineral fibres and also recent studies of metal oxide NFs; less than 1 % dissolution after 56 days in phagolysosomal fluid has been reported for biopersistent crocidolite asbestos, whereas non-biopersistent MMVF22 showed 50 % dissolution in the same timeframe (Maxim et al., 2002). Biopersistent fibres or very slowly dissolving NFs should be used as benchmark materials for inclusion in acellular assays to confirm DN outcomes for grouping target NFs as very slowing dissolving HARNs.

attributes.name: DN_dissolution_outcome_in_lung_lining_fluid
attributes.note:

expressions.name: shells
expressions.note: All chemical constituents of the nanomaterial having 'shell as constituent_role.

decendents.note: A substance will be considered as mono-constituent if one constituent is present at a concentration of at least 80% (w/w) and the impurities make up no more than 20% (w/w),  Intentionally added substances other than those added to stabilise the substance are separate substances that are not to be considered in the main mass balance.

including any additive necessary to preserve its stability and any impurity deriving from the process used,
 but excluding any solvent which may be separated without affecting the stability of the substance or changing its composition.'
 
 REACH encompasses substances (mono-constituent, multi-constituent, UVCB substances and 'nanoform' (new!)) which all should be addressed as substances.

'a chemical element and its compounds in the natural state or obtained by any manufacturing process, 
including any additive necessary to preserve its stability and any impurity deriving from the process used,
 but excluding any solvent which may be separated without affecting the stability of the substance or changing its composition.'

Abstract medium class, representing all potential external media and test media the targeted material can be in.

Material representing the 'relevant medium'  like actcual river water, soil and sediment.  

The composition of the different eco media is determined by the specific constituents added. Each zone/field of an environmental compartment has its own eco medium.
Eco medium representing the air which can be used in zones of both indoor and outdoor air compartments.
Eco medium used to describe the soil composition and its specific properties.

attributes.name: packing_density
attributes.note: Packing density (p) integrates bulk density, structure and organic matter content to express compactness of soils.

attributes.name: macro_porosity
attributes.note: Can be derived from sand, clay and silt content

decendents.note: Eco medium used to describe the sediment composition and its specific properties.
Eco medium representing an aquatic medium like freshwater or marinewater. Besides its composition it also has specific properties like flowtype and flowrate.
Simulated natural fresh waters [ISO-TR 19057-2017, 10.4.2].
Simulated sea water [ISO-TR 19057-2017, 10.4.3]
Simulated estuarine waters [ISO-TR 19057-2017, 10.4.4]
Material representing biological media like (like the lysosomal compartment of a cell).
Abstract medium class, representing all potential external media and test media the targeted material can be in.

'A pure chemical compound composed of a single molecule.' [Reach]

Atoms, ions and molecules smaller than 1 nm in all dimensions, larger molecules within the nanoscale are considered nano-objects.

A 'chemical' cannot own constituents of itself anymore.

attributes.name: coating_thickness
attributes.note: Only relevant in case constituent_role = 'coating', thickness of the coating in nm.

decendents.note:
A mixture is defined in REACH

A mixture consists of several different substances. Each individual component substance in a mixture needs to be identified, and when required registered according to REACH and/or  notified according to CLP either by the substance manufacturer or by the importer of the mixture

Individual articles/ product items, composed of one or more materials with a quantified amount. At least one 'material' must be added as a constituent. For example: tennis rackets, bumpers, diesel filters, can of paint, tiles, T-shirts, socks, bags filled with powder, sun screen spray. But also, used and articles to be disposed.
 
“article: means an object which during production is given a special shape, surface or design which determines its function to a greater degree than does its chemical composition” (Article 3(3) of REACH).
Abstract material, representing both nanomaterials (forms) and other substances and materials in a certain phase.
The material proxy is a conceptual class needed to allow reuse of a defined material as components of articles or nano enabled products.

expressions.name: chemistry
expressions.note: The chemisty of the original material.

decendents.note: The candidate NF proxy represents any NF within the provisional set of nanoform to be grouped.

classes.note:
CrystallineForm (phase)

One or more crystalline forms can be used to indicate the (poly)crystallinity of a solid chemical. 
Multiple chrystalline forms (including amorphous in addition) can be combined in any percentage adding up to 100%.

attributes.name: space_group
attributes.note: (Crystallographic) space group types (230 in three dimensions). (Wikipedia also used in OECD harmonised templates)

attributes.name: crystallite_size
attributes.note: The size of the crystal unit cell in nm.

attributes.name: mineral_name
attributes.note: The 'mineral name' indicates a 'chemical' of a certain crystallinity form. (e.g. rutile, anatase etc. being both TIO2(s) but with different crystal forms and as such with different phys-chem and toxicity properties)

associations.name: medium_interaction
associations.note: To deal with medium specific properties

attributes.name: DN_dissolution_in_medium_outcome
attributes.note: DN-EG1-1

decendents.note:
Each environmental compartment has one or more zones representing different fields or regions within it. A zone can either be virtual or physical.
- A virtual zone is used to separate a room in different fields (NEAR FIELD, FAR FIELD) or a river in different segments.
- A physical zone is used to separate different media classes within the same environmental compartment. (e.g. air in room and floor in room)

composites.name: zones
composites.note:
Each environmental compartment has one ore more zones representing different fields or regions within it. A zone can either be virtual or physical. 
- A virtual zone is used to separate a room in different fields (NEAR FIELD, FAR FIELD) or a river in different segments.
- A physical zone is used to separate different media classes within the same environmental compartment. (eg air in room and floor in room)

decendents.note: An eco compartment is a natural environmental compartment. (except perhaps for IndoorAir)
An abstract air compartment.
Representing the outdoor air. Sunlight, wind and rain etc..
Representing a room of certain dimensions. (perhaps to be derived from system compartments?)
Abstract class representing any natural water compartment.
A freshwater river or lake.
Salt water system, sea, ocean.
Brackish water systems
Representing the soil with certain dimensions.
Abstract class for natural sediment compartments.
Sediment in a lake or river.
Sediment in sea, ocean.
Sediment in a estuarine environment.
Natural compartment representing land where plants and animals live.
Any man made compartment.
Waste Water Treatment Plant
Sewage network
Landfill site, were final waste is dumped in.
Factory where final waste is incinerated.
The specific eco system present in a zone of an eco compartment.
The fresh water eco system representing all kind of aquatic species of different trophic levels in lakes and rivers.
The marine water eco system representing all kind of aquatic species of different trophic levels living in saltwater seas and oceans.
The soil organisms representing all kind of soil related species of different trophic levels.
The fresh water sediment organisms representing all kind of sediment related species of different trophic levels.
The salt water sediment organisms representing all kind of sediment related species of different trophic levels.
The bioorganisms used in waste water treatment plants (WWTP).
The eco system of plants, animals (including birds?) and microorganisms living on land.

enumerates.name: 'Drop shape analysis'
enumerates.note: Drop shape analysis (DSA) The contact angle is measured using the image of a sessile drop at the points of intersection (three-phase contact points) between the drop contour and the projection of the surface (baseline).

enumerates.name: 'Wilhelmy plate method'
enumerates.note: The force acting in the tensile direction when moving a plate-shaped solid vertically in a liquid is measured. This force depends on the contact angle as well as on the surface tension and the wetted length.

enumerates.name: 'Washburn method'
enumerates.note: Powder contact angle measurement using the Washburn method: The increase in weight of an immersed powder-filled tube is measured with respect to time. The rate of rise of the liquid column depends, among other things, on the contact angle.

enumerates.name: 'Top-view distance method'
enumerates.note: The curvature of the drop surface associated with the contact angle is measured using the distance between light spots which are reflected on the top of a drop surface.

enumerates.name: 'Cell culture medium, RPMI supplemented with 1% pen/strep, 10% FBS, 1% L-glutamine'
enumerates.note:
RPMI 1640, also known as RPMI medium, is a growth medium used in cell culture.
pen/strep,  Penicillin-Streptomycin for cell culture
Fetal bovine serum (FBS) is used as a growth supplement for the in vitro cell culture of eukaryotic cells.
L-glutamine is an amino acid supplement commonly added to mammalian cell culture media. L-glutamine serves as an auxiliary energy source, especially when cells are rapidly dividing and also can be used by cells as a source of nitrogen for the synthesis of proteins, nucleic acids, etc.

enumerates.name: 'NANOGENTOX dispersion media'
enumerates.note:
NANOGENOTX dispersion media: NANOGENOTOX dispersion protocol (Jensen et al., 2011).
A 2.56 mg/ml stock dispersion is prepared by prewetting powder in 0.5 vol% ethanol ( 96% purity) followed by dispersion in 0.05 wt% BSA-water during 16 minutes of probe sonication. For harmonization of dispersion energy and stabilities it is recommended to produce a 6-8 ml dispersion in the 20 ml tall glass scintillation vials. It takes 15.36 mg to produce a 6 ml 2.56 mg/ml stock dispersion.

expressions.name: actual_tier
expressions.note:
The actual tier is the highest derived tier level for which the assay results may be used for. E.g. if the highest tier level = 2, this means that the results may be used at TL 1 and TL 2, but NOT TL 3.
The highest tier level may depend on the medium used, duration etc. It is always equal or higher to the minimum tier.
